lines.text: U.S SENATE COMMITTEE ON FNVIRONMLNT AND PUBLIC WONKS
WASHINGTON - The Subcommittee on Clean Air and Nuclear Regulation will hear
from U.S. Surgeon General Joycelyn Elders, EPA Administrator Carol Browner and
others about the health risks of second-hand smoke at a hearing on Wednesday,
Chairman Joe Lieberman, D-Connecticut, announced today.
Wednesuay's hearing begins at 9:30 a.m. in Room 216 of the Hart Senate
Office Building. A witness list is attached.
The hearing will focus on the Environmental Protection Agency's December 1992
report on second-hand smoke, and thc controversy that has surrounded it. The report
is responsible for approximarely 3,ooo lung cancer deaths annually in the U.S.;
contains more than 4,o00 substances-- including more than 40 known or
EPA's Science Advisory Board has consistently ranked pollution in indoor air- where
Americans spend 9o percent of their time- among the top four environmental risks to
EPA, the Defense Department, the U.S. Postal Service and other goverminent agencies
have banned or restricted smoking in the workplae. A bil introduced by Sen. Frank
Lautenberg, DN.J., seek: to sharply limit smoking in goverment buildings: the House
of Representatives passed! a similar law last November.

SECOND-HAND SMOKE AT ISSUE WEDNESDAY
Elders, Browner, others to testify
WASHINGTON - The Subcommittee on Clean Air and Nuclear Regulation will hear
from U.S. Surgeon General Joycelyn Elders, EPA Administrator Carol Browner and
others about the health risks of second-hand smoke at a hearing on Wednesday,
Chairman Joe Lieberman, D-Connecticut, announced today.
Wednesuay's hearing begins at 9:30 a.m. in Room 216 of the Hart Senate
Office Building. A witness list is attached.
The hearing will focus on the Environmental Protection Agency's December 1992
report on second-hand smoke, and thc controversy that has surrounded it. The report
found that second-hand smoke:
is a human lung carcinogen;
is responsible for approximarely 3,ooo lung cancer deaths annually in the U.S.;
contains more than 4,o00 substances-- including more than 40 known or
suspected to cause cancer.
2023615030
EPA's Science Advisory Board has consistently ranked pollution in indoor air- where
Americans spend 9o percent of their time- among the top four environmental risks to
the public's health.
EPA, the Defense Department, the U.S. Postal Service and other goverminent agencies
have banned or restricted smoking in the workplae. A bil introduced by Sen. Frank
Lautenberg, DN.J., seek: to sharply limit smoking in goverment buildings: the House
of Representatives passed! a similar law last November.
